title: Standard Form of Hyperbola with Center (h,k)
text: The standard form of the equation of a hyperbola with center (h,k) and transverse axis parallel to the x-axis is $$\frac{{\left(x-h\right)}^2}{a^2}-\frac{{\left(y-k\right)}^2}{b^2}=1$$ where the length of the transverse axis is 2a the coordinates of the vertices are (h+a,k),(h-a,k) the length of the conjugate axis is 2b the coordinates of the co-vertices are (h,k+b),(h,k-b) the distance between the foci is 2c, where $$c^2=a^2+b^2$$ the coordinates of the foci are (h+c,k),(h-c,k) The asymptotes of the hyperbola coincide with the diagonals of the central rectangle. The length of the rectangle is 2a and its width is 2b. The slopes of the diagonals are $$\frac{b}{a}$$ and $$\frac{-b}{a}$$, and each diagonal passes through the center (h,k). Using the point-slope formula, it is simple to show that the equations of the asymptotes are $$y=\frac{b}{a} \left(x-h\right)+k$$ and $$y=\frac{-b}{a} \left(x-h\right)+k$$. (See the left image) The standard form of the equation of a hyperbola with center (h,k) and transverse axis parallel to the y-axis is $$\frac{{\left(y-k\right)}^2}{a^2}-\frac{{\left(x-h\right)}^2}{b^2}=1$$ where the length of the transverse axis is 2a the coordinates of the vertices are (h,k+a),(h,k-a) the length of the conjugate axis is 2b the coordinates of the co-vertices are (h+b,k),(h-b,k) the distance between the foci is 2c, where $$c^2=a^2+b^2$$ the coordinates of the foci are (h,k+c),(h,k-c) Using the reasoning above, the equations of the asymptotes are $$y=\frac{a}{b} \left(x-h\right)+k$$ and $$y=\frac{-a}{b} \left(x-h\right)+k$$.\n##figure1.gif##

title: Transverse Axis
text: Which axis is transverse axis on? We can tell based on the coordinates of the vertices and foci.

title: Appropriate Standard Form
text: Since the transverse axis is on the y-axis, which standard form for hyperbola should we use?

title: Center
text: We start by identifying the center. The center is halfway between the vertices (1,-2) and (1,8). We can apply the midpoint formula $$(h,k)=(\frac{x_1+x_2}{2},\frac{y_1+y_2}{2})$$. What is the center (h,k)?

title: Vertices
text: It is given that vertices are (1,-2) and (1,8). The length of the transverse axis, 2a, is bounded by the vertices. We can thus find a by dividing the length between the two vertices by 2. What is a in the standard form of hyperbola?

title: Foci
text: It is given that foci are (1,-10) and (1,16). The coordinates of foci are also given by $$(h,k+c)$$ and (h,k-c) where c is the distance of the foci from the center. We can use $$(h,k+c)=(1,16)$$ with $$k=3$$ that we found earlier to find c. What is c associated with the hyperbola?

title: Finding b
text: We know that $$c^2=a^2+b^2$$, we can thus rearrange the equation to $$b=\sqrt{c^2-a^2}$$. With the a and c previously found, what is b?

title: Equation
text: Having found h, k, a and b, we can now substitute them into the standard form equation $$\frac{{\left(y-k\right)}^2}{a^2}-\frac{{\left(x-h\right)}^2}{b^2}=1$$
